item.title: Jacobi Quartics
item.description: This is a short note on Jacobi quartics and its relationship with elliptic curves. Definition An elliptic curve in Jacobi quartic form is a curve of the form $J_a: y^2 = x^4 + 2ax^2 + 1$, where $\det(J)$, which is some multiple of $a^2 - 1$ here, is nonzero. This model of elliptic curves is important as it provides quicker point arithmetic. We shall prove that the curve $J_a$ is birationally equivalent to $E_a: 2v^2 = u^3 - 2au^2 + (a^2 - 1)u$.

item.title: Bernoulli Polynomials
item.description: Please note that $p$ does not denote a prime, but instead usually an integer $p \geq 0$. Existing lemmas Definition by recurrence: $$ B_n = 1 - \sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} \binom{n}{k} \frac{B_k}{n + 1 - k} $$ $$ B_n(x) = \sum_{k = 0}^n \binom{n}{k} B_{n - k}x^k $$ Faulhaber’s theorem: $$ \sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} k^p = \sum_{i = 0}^p B_i \binom{p + 1}{i} \frac{n^{p + 1 - i}}{p + 1} $$

item.title: Investigating Pythagorean Triplets (1)
item.description: Notes of Pythagorean Triplets This is a short article re-deriving the Tree of (primitive) Pythagorean Triplets, as well as a few interesting generalisations. Firstly, let’s begin with the equation $x^2 + y^2 = z^2$. A triplet $(x, y, z)$ satisfying the equation is called a Pythagorean Triplet, abbreviated PT. If we further have that $\gcd(x, y, z) = 1$, then we say that $(x, y, z)$ is a primitive PT, abbreviated PPT.
